elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs)-based fluorescent sensors have attracted much attention due to their high selectivity, sensitivity, and operability. However, the poor stability of MOFs seriously limits their applications in detecting toxic species in water system. Herein, taking advantage of the high chemical stability of the metal phosphonate bond, the easy crystallinity of carboxylate, and the π-conjugated benzene, a new luminescent MOF with three-dimensional network has been successfully synthesized using the predesigned 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbdc) ligand. [Cd2(pbdc)­(H2O)3] (1) not only possesses excellent stability in water and some organic solvents but also can remain structural integrity in acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions with pH value ranging from 4 to 10. Remarkably, 1 can efficiently and sensitively probe Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions over other metal ions in an aqueous system. The quenching constant of K sv and detection limit are 1.57 × 106 M–1 and 38.9 nM for Cu2+ ions, 2.86 × 105 M–1 and 139.0 nM for Al3+ ions, and 1.86 × 105 M–1 and 167.6 nM for Fe3+ ions, respectively. This work proposes a feasible strategy for constructing stable MOFs as highly sensitive luminescent sensors in water system.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)-based fluorescent sensors have attracted much attention due to their high selectivity, sensitivity, and operability. However, the poor stability of MOFs seriously limits their applications in detecting toxic species in water system. Herein, taking advantage of the high chemical stability of the metal phosphonate bond, the easy crystallinity of carboxylate, and the π-conjugated benzene, a new luminescent MOF with three-dimensional network has been successfully synthesized using the predesigned 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbdc) ligand. [Cd2(pbdc)(H2O)3] (1) not only possesses excellent stability in water and some organic solvents but also can remain structural integrity in acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions with pH value ranging from 4 to 10. Remarkably, 1 can efficiently and sensitively probe Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions over other metal ions in an aqueous system. The quenching constant of K sv and detection limit are 1.57 × 106 M-1 and 38.9 nM for Cu2+ ions, 2.86 × 105 M-1 and 139.0 nM for Al3+ ions, and 1.86 × 105 M-1 and 167.6 nM for Fe3+ ions, respectively. This work proposes a feasible strategy for constructing stable MOFs as highly sensitive luminescent sensors in water system.

elements.content: A new luminescent MOF with three-dimensional network has been successfully synthesized using the predesigned 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbdc) ligand. [Cd2(pbdc)­(H2O)3] (1) not only possesses excellent stability in water and some organic solvents but also can keep its structural integrity in acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions with a pH value ranging from 4 to 10.
elements.clean_text: A new luminescent MOF with three-dimensional network has been successfully synthesized using the predesigned 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbdc) ligand. [Cd2(pbdc)(H2O)3] (1) not only possesses excellent stability in water and some organic solvents but also can keep its structural integrity in acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions with a pH value ranging from 4 to 10.

elements.content: As a class of porous crystalline solid materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) that built on the inherent coordination between organic linkers and metal nodes (metal ions or metal clusters) are regarded as desirable materials for applications in gas storage and separation, removal of toxic materials, catalysis, luminescent sensing, and so on. Despite showing many attractive advantages, such as tunability and designability of structures and functions, the practical applications of most MOFs are unfortunately limited due to their poor stability, especially in aqueous environment. Thus, many efforts have been made to improve the stability of MOF materials. First, the most commonly used strategy is based on Pearson’s hard/soft acid/base principle, the combination of hard high-valent metal ions (i.e., Ti4+, Zr4+, Al3+, etc.) and hard carboxylate-based ligands, or the soft divalent metal ions (i.e., Zn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, etc.) and soft ligands with nitrogen as terminal coordination site, as confirmed by the well-known MIL-101, UIO-66, and ZIF-8. Second, by purposefully designing hydrophobic interfaces through direct synthesis or hydrophobic surfaces by postsynthetic modification, the resulting framework can avoid suffering an attack from water molecules. For example, Yu and Jiang et al. successfully coated hydrophobic polydimethysiloxane on the surface of MOF (selected MOF-5, HKUST-1, and ZnBT as representative) materials to significantly enhance their moisture or water stability. Third, enhancing the connectivity between metal and ligand is also feasible. Such as Ma and Shi et al. remarkably enhanced Cu-MOF water/chemical stabilities through increasing the Cu–N bond strength after replacing the tetrazole moiety of 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid with 1,2,3-triazole or pyrazole. Although some stable MOFs showing good resistance to water, acidic/alkaline, and other harsh conditions have been reported, great efforts are still needed in developing state of the art materials with peculiar architectures and excellent properties for practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As a class of porous crystalline solid materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) that built on the inherent coordination between organic linkers and metal nodes (metal ions or metal clusters) are regarded as desirable materials for applications in gas storage and separation, removal of toxic materials, catalysis, luminescent sensing, and so on. Despite showing many attractive advantages, such as tunability and designability of structures and functions, the practical applications of most MOFs are unfortunately limited due to their poor stability, especially in aqueous environment. Thus, many efforts have been made to improve the stability of MOF materials. First, the most commonly used strategy is based on Pearson's hard/soft acid/base principle, the combination of hard high-valent metal ions (i.e., Ti4+, Zr4+, Al3+, etc.) and hard carboxylate-based ligands, or the soft divalent metal ions (i.e., Zn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, etc.) and soft ligands with nitrogen as terminal coordination site, as confirmed by the well-known MIL-101, UIO-66, and ZIF-8. Second, by purposefully designing hydrophobic interfaces through direct synthesis or hydrophobic surfaces by postsynthetic modification, the resulting framework can avoid suffering an attack from water molecules. For example, Yu and Jiang et al. successfully coated hydrophobic polydimethysiloxane on the surface of MOF (selected MOF-5, HKUST-1, and ZnBT as representative) materials to significantly enhance their moisture or water stability. Third, enhancing the connectivity between metal and ligand is also feasible. Such as Ma and Shi et al. remarkably enhanced Cu-MOF water/chemical stabilities through increasing the Cu-N bond strength after replacing the tetrazole moiety of 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid with 1,2,3-triazole or pyrazole. Although some stable MOFs showing good resistance to water, acidic/alkaline, and other harsh conditions have been reported, great efforts are still needed in developing state of the art materials with peculiar architectures and excellent properties for practical applications.

elements.content: Recently, MOF-based fluorescent sensors that can detect toxic species in environmental and ecological systems show fascinating advantages of rapid response, simplicity, and selectivity. As for the metal ions, copper (Cu2+), aluminum (Al3+), and iron (Fe3+) ions are widely applied in various materials and industrial production. As is well-known, the excess release of them can have an effect on the surrounding ecosystem and directly threaten our human health, resulting in many diseases. Hence, it is meaningful to selectively and efficiently detect these metal ions considering ecological security. As potential metal ion sensors, MOFs show remarkable performance for the following reasons: (1) their photoluminescent properties are diversified, which can be extensively tunable by variation of metal centers, ligands, guests, or even excitation energies, and their specific luminescent changes in the presence of metal ions are easily detected through “turn-off” or “turn-on” fluorescence response based on host–guest chemistry; (2) the structural designability and chemical diversity of MOFs enable researchers to modify the environment of both the pores and surface by decorating with appropriate functional groups that can act as metal-binding sites on the ligands; (3) as solid sensing materials, MOFs can be separated from water by filtration or centrifugation, leaving the system uncontaminated. However, the known highly efficient MOF-based sensors are usually detecting metal ions in organic solvents while not in water systems due to their poor water stability. For example, Liu et al. reported a porphyrin based MOF having outstanding sensing ability for Cu2+ ions with high K sv (represent quenching constant) of 4.5 × 105 M–1 and low detection limit of 67 nM in mixed N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and water solution. Yan et al. reported an Eu-MOF based on 2-aminoterephthalic acid for sensing of Al3+ ions with K sv of 3.8 × 104 M–1 and detection limit of 10 μM in DMF solution. Zheng et al. reported a Dy–Zn MOF based on 4,5-imidazole dicarboxylic acid and imidazole ligand for sensing of Fe3+ ions with K sv of 9.29 × 105 M–1 and detection limit of 0.1 μM in dimethyl sulfoxide solution. In a water system, K sv values of MOF-based fluorescent sensors for Cu2+ and Al3+ ions are only with orders of magnitude of 103–104 M–1, which needs to be improved for highly sensitive detection in ultralow concentration of metal ions. Considering this, it is highly desirable to design and synthesize highly stable MOFs that show excellent sensing performance in aqueous systems.
elements.clean_text: Recently, MOF-based fluorescent sensors that can detect toxic species in environmental and ecological systems show fascinating advantages of rapid response, simplicity, and selectivity. As for the metal ions, copper (Cu2+), aluminum (Al3+), and iron (Fe3+) ions are widely applied in various materials and industrial production. As is well-known, the excess release of them can have an effect on the surrounding ecosystem and directly threaten our human health, resulting in many diseases. Hence, it is meaningful to selectively and efficiently detect these metal ions considering ecological security. As potential metal ion sensors, MOFs show remarkable performance for the following reasons: (1) their photoluminescent properties are diversified, which can be extensively tunable by variation of metal centers, ligands, guests, or even excitation energies, and their specific luminescent changes in the presence of metal ions are easily detected through "turn-off" or "turn-on" fluorescence response based on host-guest chemistry; (2) the structural designability and chemical diversity of MOFs enable researchers to modify the environment of both the pores and surface by decorating with appropriate functional groups that can act as metal-binding sites on the ligands; (3) as solid sensing materials, MOFs can be separated from water by filtration or centrifugation, leaving the system uncontaminated. However, the known highly efficient MOF-based sensors are usually detecting metal ions in organic solvents while not in water systems due to their poor water stability. For example, Liu et al. reported a porphyrin based MOF having outstanding sensing ability for Cu2+ ions with high K sv (represent quenching constant) of 4.5 × 105 M-1 and low detection limit of 67 nM in mixed N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and water solution. Yan et al. reported an Eu-MOF based on 2-aminoterephthalic acid for sensing of Al3+ ions with K sv of 3.8 × 104 M-1 and detection limit of 10 μM in DMF solution. Zheng et al. reported a Dy-Zn MOF based on 4,5-imidazole dicarboxylic acid and imidazole ligand for sensing of Fe3+ ions with K sv of 9.29 × 105 M-1 and detection limit of 0.1 μM in dimethyl sulfoxide solution. In a water system, K sv values of MOF-based fluorescent sensors for Cu2+ and Al3+ ions are only with orders of magnitude of 103-104 M-1, which needs to be improved for highly sensitive detection in ultralow concentration of metal ions. Considering this, it is highly desirable to design and synthesize highly stable MOFs that show excellent sensing performance in aqueous systems.

elements.content: For the construction of robust and luminescent MOFs, the predesign of organic ligands with desired structure and function is of great importance. Compared to the popularly studied luminescence MOFs constructed by nitrogen or carboxylate-based ligands with good crystallinity ability, phosphonate-containing MOFs are relatively rare although C–PO3 bonds and metal phosphonate bond have high thermal, hydrolytic, and chemical stability. Herein, combining the high chemical stability of metal phosphonate bond, the easy crystallinity of carboxylate, and the π-conjugated benzene, we present a new MOF constructed from 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbdc) (see ) and Cd­(NO3)2 under hydrothermal condition. [Cd2(pbdc)­(H2O)3] (1) has a three-dimensional (3D) framework with luminescent property and excellent stability in an aqueous system and some common organic solvents. The structural integrity can be even well remained in water or in acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions with pH value ranging from 4 to 10. This compound exhibits outstanding luminescent sensing ability for sensitive and selective detection of Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions in water system. Particularly, the quenching efficiencies for Cu2+ and Al3+ ions are highly enhanced compared to the known MOF-based sensors.
elements.clean_text: For the construction of robust and luminescent MOFs, the predesign of organic ligands with desired structure and function is of great importance. Compared to the popularly studied luminescence MOFs constructed by nitrogen or carboxylate-based ligands with good crystallinity ability, phosphonate-containing MOFs are relatively rare although C-PO3 bonds and metal phosphonate bond have high thermal, hydrolytic, and chemical stability. Herein, combining the high chemical stability of metal phosphonate bond, the easy crystallinity of carboxylate, and the π-conjugated benzene, we present a new MOF constructed from 5-phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (H4pbdc) (see ) and Cd(NO3)2 under hydrothermal condition. [Cd2(pbdc)(H2O)3] (1) has a three-dimensional (3D) framework with luminescent property and excellent stability in an aqueous system and some common organic solvents. The structural integrity can be even well remained in water or in acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions with pH value ranging from 4 to 10. This compound exhibits outstanding luminescent sensing ability for sensitive and selective detection of Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions in water system. Particularly, the quenching efficiencies for Cu2+ and Al3+ ions are highly enhanced compared to the known MOF-based sensors.

elements.clean_text: 1  Chemical Structure of 5-Phosphonobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic Acid (H4pbdc)

elements.content: Cd­(NO3)3·6H2O (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H4pbdc (36 mg, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in H2O (5 mL) under stirred conditions, followed by the addition of 1 mL of water containing NH4F (40 mg, 1.08 mmol). Then the solution was sealed into a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless-steel vessel, which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 5 days, then gradually cooled to room temperature under ambient conditions. White stick crystals of 1 were collected after washing with water and then dried in air with 81 wt % yield based on H4pbdc. Elemental analysis (%) for 1, C8H9PO10Cd2: C 18.45, H 1.75. Anal. Calcd: C 18.71, H 1.77. IR (cm–1): 3337 (m), 3007 (m), 1658 (w), 1560 (s), 1533 (s), 1449 (w), 1419 (m), 1382 (m), 1205 (w), 1116 (s), 1042 (s), 972 (s), 775 (m), 722 (s), 682 (w), 597 (m), 449 (w) (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Cd2(pbdc)(H2O)3] (1)

Cd(NO3)3⋅6H2O (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H4pbdc (36 mg, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in H2O (5 mL) under stirred conditions, followed by the addition of 1 mL of water containing NH4F (40 mg, 1.08 mmol). Then the solution was sealed into a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless-steel vessel, which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 5 days, then gradually cooled to room temperature under ambient conditions. White stick crystals of 1 were collected after washing with water and then dried in air with 81 wt % yield based on H4pbdc. Elemental analysis (%) for 1, C8H9PO10Cd2: C 18.45, H 1.75. Anal. Calcd: C 18.71, H 1.77. IR (cm-1): 3337 (m), 3007 (m), 1658 (w), 1560 (s), 1533 (s), 1449 (w), 1419 (m), 1382 (m), 1205 (w), 1116 (s), 1042 (s), 972 (s), 775 (m), 722 (s), 682 (w), 597 (m), 449 (w) (Figure S1).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer for compound 1 with graphite monochromated Mo–Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 293 K. Data processing was performed using the SAINT processing program. The structure was solved through direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares with the SHELX-2014 program. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The final formula of 1 was derived from crystallographic data combined with elemental and thermogravimetric analyses (Figure S2) data. Crystallographic data for 1 (1836782) has been deposited with Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. A summary of the related crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1 are shown in Table S1. The selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are given in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer for compound 1 with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 293 K. Data processing was performed using the SAINT processing program. The structure was solved through direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares with the SHELX-2014 program. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The final formula of 1 was derived from crystallographic data combined with elemental and thermogravimetric analyses (Figure S2) data. Crystallographic data for 1 (1836782) has been deposited with Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. A summary of the related crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1 are shown in Table S1. The selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are given in Table S2.

elements.content: Compound 1 (0.5 mg) was well-dispersed in 2 mL of H2O by sonicating for one hour to form the suspension; then certain amounts of M­(NO3) z (Mz+ = Na+, K+, Sr2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Hg2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cr3+, Fe3+, Al3+ with concentration of 1 mM) were added to a quartz cuvette containing the suspension of 1 in 2 mL of H2O for luminescence detection experiment by titration. Then the quenching curves were quantitatively analyzed by the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation: I o/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I o and I are fluorescence intensity before and after the addition of the analyte, K sv is the quenching constant (M–1), and [M] is molar concentration of analyte. The detection limit is calculated according to the IUPAC recommendation of 3σ/slope, where the standard deviation σ is estimated by ten repeated fluorescent measurements of blank suspension of 1, and the slope value is obtained using a calibration curve of the fluorescence intensity against target ions concentration.
elements.clean_text:
Experiment of Luminescent Detection

Compound 1 (0.5 mg) was well-dispersed in 2 mL of H2O by sonicating for one hour to form the suspension; then certain amounts of M(NO3) z  (Mz+ = Na+, K+, Sr2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Hg2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cr3+, Fe3+, Al3+ with concentration of 1 mM) were added to a quartz cuvette containing the suspension of 1 in 2 mL of H2O for luminescence detection experiment by titration. Then the quenching curves were quantitatively analyzed by the Stern-Volmer (S-V) equation: I o/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I o and I are fluorescence intensity before and after the addition of the analyte, K sv is the quenching constant (M-1), and [M] is molar concentration of analyte. The detection limit is calculated according to the IUPAC recommendation of 3σ/slope, where the standard deviation σ is estimated by ten repeated fluorescent measurements of blank suspension of 1, and the slope value is obtained using a calibration curve of the fluorescence intensity against target ions concentration.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in an orthorhombic system with a space group of P21212. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd2+ ions, one pbdc linker, and three-coordinated H2O molecules (Figure S3). In the structure of 1, the Cd1 is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two carboxylate and three phosphonate groups belonging to different pbdc linkers. Cd2 adopts another six-coordinated mode defined by three H2O molecules, one carboxylic oxygen atom from one pbdc linker, and two phosphonate oxygen atoms from another linker (a). The Cd–O distance varies from 2.059 to 2.444 Å, which is close to the previously reported data. As shown in b, the carboxylate groups in pbdc linker adopt two different coordination modes: bridging bismonodentate node and chelating bisdentate node, while the phosphonate group acts as a tetradentate ligand chelating and bridging four Cd atoms. Thus, Cd1 and Cd2 are connected by phosphonate and carboxylate groups to form an infinite double metal chain (c), which is further bridged by pbdc linkers to generate a 3D neutral architecture (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in an orthorhombic system with a space group of P21212. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd2+ ions, one pbdc linker, and three-coordinated H2O molecules (Figure S3). In the structure of 1, the Cd1 is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from two carboxylate and three phosphonate groups belonging to different pbdc linkers. Cd2 adopts another six-coordinated mode defined by three H2O molecules, one carboxylic oxygen atom from one pbdc linker, and two phosphonate oxygen atoms from another linker (a). The Cd-O distance varies from 2.059 to 2.444 Å, which is close to the previously reported data. As shown in b, the carboxylate groups in pbdc linker adopt two different coordination modes: bridging bismonodentate node and chelating bisdentate node, while the phosphonate group acts as a tetradentate ligand chelating and bridging four Cd atoms. Thus, Cd1 and Cd2 are connected by phosphonate and carboxylate groups to form an infinite double metal chain (c), which is further bridged by pbdc linkers to generate a 3D neutral architecture (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Cd1 and Cd2; (b) coordination mode of the pbdc ligand; (c) 1D infinite double metal chains; (d) 3D architecture of 1 viewed along the y axis (color modes: Cd cyan, O red, P yellow, C gray; hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Cd1 and Cd2; (b) coordination mode of the pbdc ligand; (c) 1D infinite double metal chains; (d) 3D architecture of 1 viewed along the y axis (color modes: Cd cyan, O red, P yellow, C gray; hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: The PXRD patterns confirm the phase purity of compound 1 (). Significantly, this compound exhibits excellent stability in water and common organic solvents, as well as in acidic or alkaline aqueous system. PXRD studies reveal that the structural integrity remains after treatment in water for 2 weeks or organic solvents for 3 days ( and Figure S4). Meanwhile, the framework integrity can be well retained in acidic or alkaline aqueous solution with pH value range varying from 4 to 10 for 24 h at room temperature ().
elements.clean_text:
Stability of Compound 1 

The PXRD patterns confirm the phase purity of compound 1 (). Significantly, this compound exhibits excellent stability in water and common organic solvents, as well as in acidic or alkaline aqueous system. PXRD studies reveal that the structural integrity remains after treatment in water for 2 weeks or organic solvents for 3 days ( and Figure S4). Meanwhile, the framework integrity can be well retained in acidic or alkaline aqueous solution with pH value range varying from 4 to 10 for 24 h at room temperature ().

elements.content: PXRD patterns of simulated and experimental samples of 1 before and after treatment in water and acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns of simulated and experimental samples of 1 before and after treatment in water and acidic/alkaline aqueous solutions.

elements.content: As mentioned above, stable MOFs can be constructed from carboxylic ligands and high-valent metal ions (such as Zr4+) based on Pearson’s hard/soft acid/base principle, and the stable MOFs built from divalent metal ions and carboxylic ligands were gradually reported recently by different strategies. The high stability of compound 1 in a water system may result from (i) introducing a phosphono into the ligand, forming strong bonds between PO3 and metal center; or (ii) the infinite double metal chain and the relative highly dense 3D framework. The synergistic effects of these factors enhance the stability of the material. Obviously, the robust framework of compound 1 with outstanding chemical stability endows it with more opportunities in the practical application as a metal ion sensor.
elements.clean_text: As mentioned above, stable MOFs can be constructed from carboxylic ligands and high-valent metal ions (such as Zr4+) based on Pearson's hard/soft acid/base principle, and the stable MOFs built from divalent metal ions and carboxylic ligands were gradually reported recently by different strategies. The high stability of compound 1 in a water system may result from (i) introducing a phosphono into the ligand, forming strong bonds between PO3 and metal center; or (ii) the infinite double metal chain and the relative highly dense 3D framework. The synergistic effects of these factors enhance the stability of the material. Obviously, the robust framework of compound 1 with outstanding chemical stability endows it with more opportunities in the practical application as a metal ion sensor.

elements.content: Considering the fact that MOFs constructed by d10 metal ions and aromatic organic ligands are promising candidates for luminescent materials, the fluorescence property of compound 1 has been investigated at room temperature. The solid luminescence of 1 shows an intense broad emission band centered at 441 nm upon excitation at 327 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-centered luminescence of H4pbdc that exhibits a similar emission band centered at 427 nm under 357 nm excitation (). The suspension of 1 in water shows an emission at 418 nm upon excitation at 313 nm. Moreover, considering the practical use and the fact that industrial effluent and polluted rivers are usually acidic, we also measured the fluorescence intensity of compound 1 dispersed in aqueous solution with pH ≤ 7. The results show that the fluorescence intensities of 1 are almost unchanged with different pH values in the range of 4–7 (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence and Sensing Properties

Considering the fact that MOFs constructed by d10 metal ions and aromatic organic ligands are promising candidates for luminescent materials, the fluorescence property of compound 1 has been investigated at room temperature. The solid luminescence of 1 shows an intense broad emission band centered at 441 nm upon excitation at 327 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-centered luminescence of H4pbdc that exhibits a similar emission band centered at 427 nm under 357 nm excitation (). The suspension of 1 in water shows an emission at 418 nm upon excitation at 313 nm. Moreover, considering the practical use and the fact that industrial effluent and polluted rivers are usually acidic, we also measured the fluorescence intensity of compound 1 dispersed in aqueous solution with pH ≤ 7. The results show that the fluorescence intensities of 1 are almost unchanged with different pH values in the range of 4-7 (Figure S5).

elements.content: Emission (solid line) and excitation (dashed line) spectra of H4pbdc (red) and compound 1 in solid state (green) and in water (blue), respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  Emission (solid line) and excitation (dashed line) spectra of H4pbdc (red) and compound 1 in solid state (green) and in water (blue), respectively.

elements.content: The fluorescence property and the excellent stability of 1 stimulate us to investigate its fluorescence detection application in water. A series of luminescence-based sensing experiments have been performed with consecutive titration of metal ions to the suspension of 1 in water. As shown in , compound 1 shows selective sensing ability toward different metal ions with the luminescent quenching percentage (QP) sequence of Cu2+ > Al3+ > Fe3+ > Cr3+ > Ni2+ > Co2+ > Zn2+ > Sr2+ > Na+ > Ca2+ > Hg2+ > Mg2+ > K+. Obviously, Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions present the highest quenching efficiency with the QP exceeding 90.3%, 83.5%, and 81.2%, respectively. The fluorescent intensity of compound 1 is significantly decreasing with the addition of solution containing Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions, respectively (a–c).
elements.clean_text: The fluorescence property and the excellent stability of 1 stimulate us to investigate its fluorescence detection application in water. A series of luminescence-based sensing experiments have been performed with consecutive titration of metal ions to the suspension of 1 in water. As shown in , compound 1 shows selective sensing ability toward different metal ions with the luminescent quenching percentage (QP) sequence of Cu2+ > Al3+ > Fe3+ > Cr3+ > Ni2+ > Co2+ > Zn2+ > Sr2+ > Na+ > Ca2+ > Hg2+ > Mg2+ > K+. Obviously, Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions present the highest quenching efficiency with the QP exceeding 90.3%, 83.5%, and 81.2%, respectively. The fluorescent intensity of compound 1 is significantly decreasing with the addition of solution containing Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions, respectively (a-c).

elements.content: Quenching percentage of fluorescence intensity upon the addition of different analytes ([analyte] = 9.9 μM).
elements.clean_text: 4  Quenching percentage of fluorescence intensity upon the addition of different analytes ([analyte] = 9.9 μM).

elements.content: (a–c) Luminescence quenching of 1 dispersed in water with gradual addition of 1 mM water solution of Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions, respectively; (d–f) the Stern–Volmer plot of I o/I versus Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions concentration, respectively (insets: the related Stern–Volmer plots at low Al3+ and Fe3+ ions concentration; the green dashed line represents the MCLs of the corresponding metal ions).
elements.clean_text: 5  (a-c) Luminescence quenching of 1 dispersed in water with gradual addition of 1 mM water solution of Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions, respectively; (d-f) the Stern-Volmer plot of I o/I versus Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions concentration, respectively (insets: the related Stern-Volmer plots at low Al3+ and Fe3+ ions concentration; the green dashed line represents the MCLs of the corresponding metal ions).

elements.content: The Stern–Volmer plot analysis exhibits a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.993) in the concentration range of 0 to 4.98 μM for Cu2+ ions (d). While for Al3+ and Fe3+ ions, the Stern–Volmer plots are nearly linear at low concentrations and subsequently bent upward at higher concentrations (e,f). The calculated K sv are 1.57 × 106, 2.86 × 105, and 1.86 × 105 M–1 for Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions, and their detection limits (DOL) are 38.9, 139.0, and 167.6 nM, respectively. Strikingly, compound 1 exhibits the best MOF-based sensing performance for Cu2+ and Al3+ ions in water with the quenching constant of K sv being improved by an order of magnitude compared to known MOF-based sensors so far (Table S3). The K sv of 1 for Fe3+ ions is close to the best value of 2.67 × 105 M–1 found in MOF materials of [(CH3)2NH2]6[Cd3L­(H2O)2]·12H2O used in aqueous phase.
elements.clean_text: The Stern-Volmer plot analysis exhibits a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.993) in the concentration range of 0 to 4.98 μM for Cu2+ ions (d). While for Al3+ and Fe3+ ions, the Stern-Volmer plots are nearly linear at low concentrations and subsequently bent upward at higher concentrations (e,f). The calculated K sv are 1.57 × 106, 2.86 × 105, and 1.86 × 105 M-1 for Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions, and their detection limits (DOL) are 38.9, 139.0, and 167.6 nM, respectively. Strikingly, compound 1 exhibits the best MOF-based sensing performance for Cu2+ and Al3+ ions in water with the quenching constant of K sv being improved by an order of magnitude compared to known MOF-based sensors so far (Table S3). The K sv of 1 for Fe3+ ions is close to the best value of 2.67 × 105 M-1 found in MOF materials of [(CH3)2NH2]6[Cd3L(H2O)2]⋅12H2O used in aqueous phase.

elements.content: The “maximum contaminant levels” (MCLs) for Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions in drinking water as required by U.S. EPA standards are 15.7, 7.4, and 5.37 μM, respectively. In this work, the calculated DOL values of compound 1 for these metal ions are far below MCLs. Experimentally, the highly sensitive detection range (0–4.98 μM) for Cu2+ ions is also below MCLs (d), indicating that 1 can quantitatively detect a trace amount of Cu2+ ions in a water system. While for Al3+ and Fe3+ ions, more broad detection range including MCLs is available, suggesting that compound 1 can effectively identify whether Al3+ or Fe3+ ions are excessive in water according to MCLs.
elements.clean_text: The "maximum contaminant levels" (MCLs) for Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions in drinking water as required by U.S. EPA standards are 15.7, 7.4, and 5.37 μM, respectively. In this work, the calculated DOL values of compound 1 for these metal ions are far below MCLs. Experimentally, the highly sensitive detection range (0-4.98 μM) for Cu2+ ions is also below MCLs (d), indicating that 1 can quantitatively detect a trace amount of Cu2+ ions in a water system. While for Al3+ and Fe3+ ions, more broad detection range including MCLs is available, suggesting that compound 1 can effectively identify whether Al3+ or Fe3+ ions are excessive in water according to MCLs.

elements.content: Furthermore, considering the practical requirements of application in wastewater or pollutant detection, the anti-interference ability of 1 for Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions sensing from the other metal ions has been explored. As shown in , the luminescence intensity of 1 remains more than 92% after addition of a mixed ions solution, whereas it is significantly quenched once the Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ion-containing aqueous solution was introduced. The results indicate that interference metal ions have a slight effect on the sensing and recognition ability of 1 toward Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions, which further confirms the excellent performance of 1 as a metal ion sensor.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, considering the practical requirements of application in wastewater or pollutant detection, the anti-interference ability of 1 for Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions sensing from the other metal ions has been explored. As shown in , the luminescence intensity of 1 remains more than 92% after addition of a mixed ions solution, whereas it is significantly quenched once the Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ion-containing aqueous solution was introduced. The results indicate that interference metal ions have a slight effect on the sensing and recognition ability of 1 toward Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions, which further confirms the excellent performance of 1 as a metal ion sensor.

elements.content: Comparison of the luminescence intensity of 1 dispersed in water: blank, after addition of mixed metal ions (Na+, K+, Sr2+, Zn2+, Hg2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cr3+; total concentration of mixed metal ions is 9.95 μM), and followed by addition of Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions, respectively ([analyte] = 9.9 μM).
elements.clean_text: 6  Comparison of the luminescence intensity of 1 dispersed in water: blank, after addition of mixed metal ions (Na+, K+, Sr2+, Zn2+, Hg2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cr3+; total concentration of mixed metal ions is 9.95 μM), and followed by addition of Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions, respectively ([analyte] = 9.9 μM).

elements.content: The possible sensing mechanism of compound 1 for Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions has been further investigated. The high stability of 1 in the presence of metal ions suggests that the sensing property of 1 does not originate from the collapse of framework (Figure S6). What’s more, the luminescent lifetime of 1 is almost unchanged before and after treatment with Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions (Table S4, Figure S7), indicating that fluorescence quenching may occur through a static mechanism. With further insight into the structure, we find that many oxygen atoms are widespread within the architecture of 1 (Figure S8), so the metal ions have more opportunities to interact with these oxygen atoms. Accordingly, we speculate that the interaction between the framework of 1 and the target metal ions (Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+) may lead to a decreased energy-transfer efficiency within the framework, thus reducing the overall luminescent intensity. The fact that the luminescence of compound 1 could not be recovered after detection of Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions even after washing by water for several times further confirms the strong interaction between the framework and these target metal ions (Figure S9). In addition, Figure S10 shows that there exists extensive overlap between UV–vis absorption spectrum of Fe3+ ions and the excitation spectrum of 1, while not for other metal ions. This means that there exists competitive adsorption for the excitation light between Fe3+ ions and 1; thus, the energy of excitation light might be partly absorbed by Fe3+ ions, reducing the adsorption of ligand and ultimately leading to the luminescence quenching.
elements.clean_text: The possible sensing mechanism of compound 1 for Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions has been further investigated. The high stability of 1 in the presence of metal ions suggests that the sensing property of 1 does not originate from the collapse of framework (Figure S6). What's more, the luminescent lifetime of 1 is almost unchanged before and after treatment with Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions (Table S4, Figure S7), indicating that fluorescence quenching may occur through a static mechanism. With further insight into the structure, we find that many oxygen atoms are widespread within the architecture of 1 (Figure S8), so the metal ions have more opportunities to interact with these oxygen atoms. Accordingly, we speculate that the interaction between the framework of 1 and the target metal ions (Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+) may lead to a decreased energy-transfer efficiency within the framework, thus reducing the overall luminescent intensity. The fact that the luminescence of compound 1 could not be recovered after detection of Cu2+, Al3+, or Fe3+ ions even after washing by water for several times further confirms the strong interaction between the framework and these target metal ions (Figure S9). In addition, Figure S10 shows that there exists extensive overlap between UV-vis absorption spectrum of Fe3+ ions and the excitation spectrum of 1, while not for other metal ions. This means that there exists competitive adsorption for the excitation light between Fe3+ ions and 1; thus, the energy of excitation light might be partly absorbed by Fe3+ ions, reducing the adsorption of ligand and ultimately leading to the luminescence quenching.

elements.content: In conclusion, a water stable 3D MOF has been successfully designed and synthesized by introducing of phosphono into the carboxylic ligand for highly efficient detection of metal ions in a water system. Studies show that compound 1 can be regarded as an excellent fluorescent turn-off sensor for probing Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions in a water system with prominent K sv and ultralow detection limit even without recyclability. The outstanding water tolerance, chemical stability in acidic/alkaline aqueous solution, and organic solvents result from the strong bond between PO3 groups and a metal center, as well as the relative highly dense 3D framework containing the infinite double metal chain. The good stability will offer more opportunities to satisfy various requirements for practical detection application. This work may provide a promising future and fascinating strategy to design novel target-sensitive MOF-based sensors with good chemical stability and then further promotes their applications in a wide variety of environmental analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a water stable 3D MOF has been successfully designed and synthesized by introducing of phosphono into the carboxylic ligand for highly efficient detection of metal ions in a water system. Studies show that compound 1 can be regarded as an excellent fluorescent turn-off sensor for probing Cu2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ ions in a water system with prominent K sv and ultralow detection limit even without recyclability. The outstanding water tolerance, chemical stability in acidic/alkaline aqueous solution, and organic solvents result from the strong bond between PO3 groups and a metal center, as well as the relative highly dense 3D framework containing the infinite double metal chain. The good stability will offer more opportunities to satisfy various requirements for practical detection application. This work may provide a promising future and fascinating strategy to design novel target-sensitive MOF-based sensors with good chemical stability and then further promotes their applications in a wide variety of environmental analysis.

cln_elements.content: Cd­(NO3)3·6H2O (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H4pbdc (36 mg, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in H2O (5 mL) under stirred conditions, followed by the addition of 1 mL of water containing NH4F (40 mg, 1.08 mmol). Then the solution was sealed into a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless-steel vessel, which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 5 days, then gradually cooled to room temperature under ambient conditions. White stick crystals of 1 were collected after washing with water and then dried in air with 81 wt % yield based on H4pbdc. Elemental analysis (%) for 1, C8H9PO10Cd2: C 18.45, H 1.75. Anal. Calcd: C 18.71, H 1.77. IR (cm–1): 3337 (m), 3007 (m), 1658 (w), 1560 (s), 1533 (s), 1449 (w), 1419 (m), 1382 (m), 1205 (w), 1116 (s), 1042 (s), 972 (s), 775 (m), 722 (s), 682 (w), 597 (m), 449 (w) (Figure S1).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Cd2(pbdc)(H2O)3] (1)

Cd(NO3)3⋅6H2O (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H4pbdc (36 mg, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in H2O (5 mL) under stirred conditions, followed by the addition of 1 mL of water containing NH4F (40 mg, 1.08 mmol). Then the solution was sealed into a 25 mL Telfon-lined stainless-steel vessel, which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 5 days, then gradually cooled to room temperature under ambient conditions. White stick crystals of 1 were collected after washing with water and then dried in air with 81 wt % yield based on H4pbdc. Elemental analysis (%) for 1, C8H9PO10Cd2: C 18.45, H 1.75. Anal. Calcd: C 18.71, H 1.77. IR (cm-1): 3337 (m), 3007 (m), 1658 (w), 1560 (s), 1533 (s), 1449 (w), 1419 (m), 1382 (m), 1205 (w), 1116 (s), 1042 (s), 972 (s), 775 (m), 722 (s), 682 (w), 597 (m), 449 (w) (Figure S1).

cln_elements.content: Considering the fact that MOFs constructed by d10 metal ions and aromatic organic ligands are promising candidates for luminescent materials, the fluorescence property of compound 1 has been investigated at room temperature. The solid luminescence of 1 shows an intense broad emission band centered at 441 nm upon excitation at 327 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-centered luminescence of H4pbdc that exhibits a similar emission band centered at 427 nm under 357 nm excitation (). The suspension of 1 in water shows an emission at 418 nm upon excitation at 313 nm. Moreover, considering the practical use and the fact that industrial effluent and polluted rivers are usually acidic, we also measured the fluorescence intensity of compound 1 dispersed in aqueous solution with pH ≤ 7. The results show that the fluorescence intensities of 1 are almost unchanged with different pH values in the range of 4–7 (Figure S5).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence and Sensing Properties

Considering the fact that MOFs constructed by d10 metal ions and aromatic organic ligands are promising candidates for luminescent materials, the fluorescence property of compound 1 has been investigated at room temperature. The solid luminescence of 1 shows an intense broad emission band centered at 441 nm upon excitation at 327 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-centered luminescence of H4pbdc that exhibits a similar emission band centered at 427 nm under 357 nm excitation (). The suspension of 1 in water shows an emission at 418 nm upon excitation at 313 nm. Moreover, considering the practical use and the fact that industrial effluent and polluted rivers are usually acidic, we also measured the fluorescence intensity of compound 1 dispersed in aqueous solution with pH ≤ 7. The results show that the fluorescence intensities of 1 are almost unchanged with different pH values in the range of 4-7 (Figure S5).

peak spectrum.condition: excitation at 313 nm, suspension in water
excitation at 357 nm, ligand-centered luminescence of H4pbdc

metadata.title:
Water Stable Metal–Organic Framework Based
on Phosphono-containing Ligand as Highly Sensitive Luminescent Sensor
toward Metal Ions
